liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The helicopter involved in the fatal military training exercise in the Whitsundays will no longer be used by the defence force. Four defence members were killed when an MRH-90 Taipan helicopter crashed in July. The fleet was grounded after the incident and investigations are ongoing. In a statement, Defence Minister Richard Marles has confirmed the Taipans will not return to flying operations before their planned withdrawal date of December 2024. You can continue reading this story by political reporter Georgia Roberts below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: BREAKING: Australian Defence Force MRH-90 Taipan helicopters involved in fatal defence crash retired early

featuredLink.title: Australian Defence Force MRH-90 Taipan helicopters involved in fatal defence crash retired early

props.alt: Taipan helicopter kicks up dust as it takes off.

children.content: (Supplied: Department of Defence)
The helicopter involved in the fatal military training exercise in the Whitsundays will
no longer be used by the defence force.
Four defence members were killed when an MRH-90 Taipan helicopter crashed in July
The fleet was grounded after the incident and investigations are ongoing.
In a statement, Defence Minister
Richard Marles
has confirmed the Taipans will not return to flying operations before their planned withdrawal date of December 2024.
You can continue reading this story by political reporter
Georgia Roberts
below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As I mentioned earlier, this morning the final report from the disability royal commission will be released. The Royal Commission into Violence, Abuse, Neglect and Exploitation of People with Disability is four-and-a-half years in the making. Senator Jordon Steele-John was on News Breakfast moments ago and reflected on the importance of the release of the report. "I think it is really important that we pay tribute to the determination, to the dedication, to the fierce advocacy of the disability community, of disabled people who have experienced violence, abuse and neglect and exploitation, who nevertheless have worked together, campaigned together, to establish this royal commission," he said. "Today is a day where we collectively, as a community, are this morning holding our breath, with a fair amount of anxiety about what the contents of the report will be. "But also a determination that we will see an end to segregation in Australia, that we will see an end to the abuse that we have been subjected to as a community, and that we will see the urgent change that is needed to end violence, abuse, neglect and exploitation wherever it exists in society."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Senator Jordon Steele-John says disability community has 'a fair amount of anxiety' about potential contents of report

children.content: As I mentioned earlier, this morning the final report from the disability royal commission will be released.

Senator
Jordon Steele-John
was on News Breakfast moments ago and reflected on the importance of the release of the report.

"I think it is really important that

"Today is a day where we collectively, as a community, are this morning holding our breath, with a
fair amount of anxiety about what the contents of the report will be.
"But
also a determination that we will see an end to segregation in Australia

, that we will see an end to the abuse that we have been subjected to as a community, and that we will see the urgent change that is needed to end violence, abuse, neglect and exploitation wherever it exists in society."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Donald Trump will not seek to move a criminal case alleging he conspired to reverse his 2020 presidential election loss in Georgia from state to federal court, his lawyers have said. The development could simplify the former US president's path to trial. Trump, the frontrunner for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination, and 18 others are charged with pressuring Georgia election officials to overturn his loss in the state to Democratic President Joe Biden in 2020. Trump and his co-defendants have denied wrongdoing and pleaded not guilty.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Breaking: Trump will not seek to move his Georgia case to federal court

children.content: Donald Trump
will not seek to move a criminal case alleging he conspired to reverse his 2020 presidential election loss in
Georgia
from state to federal court, his lawyers have said.
The development could simplify the former US president's path to trial.
Trump, the frontrunner for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination, and 18 others are
charged with pressuring Georgia election officials
to overturn his loss in the state to Democratic President Joe Biden in 2020.
Trump and his co-defendants have
denied wrongdoing and pleaded not guilty.

image.altText: tesla

props.synopsis: The US version of Fair Work has launched a lawsuit against Elon Musk's Tesla, accusing the electric car and battery giant of "widespread and ongoing racial harassment of its Black employees". Read all about today's business news on our live blog.

title.children: Australian markets to rise, as US regulator sues Tesla for 'racial harassment and retaliation'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Content warning: This post features discussion of racial abuse. Elon Musk's Tesla is being sued by the US version of FairWork for "tolerating widespread and ongoing racial harassment of its Black employees" from at least 2015 until today. The lawsuit was just filed by the US Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. The regulator's suit contains some very concerning allegations that workers in its California factory endured racial abuse, stereotyping, and vilificaton including a range of racial slurs. "Slurs were used casually and openly in high-traffic areas and at worker hubs," they allege. It further alleges that workers faced graffiti around the factory that depicted racial abuse, "including variations of the N-word, swastikas, threats, and nooses, on desks and other equipment". This graffiti was even allegedly found on new electric cars as they were rolling off the production line. Further, it found people who raised objections to this, faced retaliation including being fired. The case was lodged by the EEOC's office in the tech hub of Silicon Valley and is being led by former FBI lawyer James Baker. Tesla has been contacted for comment. This suit follows another lawsuit by Californian-based regulators about similiar issues. Earlier this year, Tesla agreed to pay one worker several million dollars after a federal jury found it failed to prevent severe racial harassment at the Californian plant. Read more of the suit here .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Tesla sued by US regulator for 'racial harassment and retaliation'

children.content: Content warning: This post features discussion of racial abuse.
Elon Musk's Tesla is being sued by the US version of FairWork for "tolerating widespread and ongoing racial harassment of its Black employees" from at least 2015 until today.
The lawsuit was just filed by the US Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
The regulator's suit contains some very concerning allegations that workers in its California factory endured racial abuse, stereotyping, and vilificaton including a range of racial slurs.
"Slurs were used casually and openly in high-traffic areas and at worker hubs," they allege.
It further alleges that workers faced graffiti around the factory that depicted racial abuse, "including variations of the N-word, swastikas, threats, and nooses, on desks and other equipment".
This graffiti was even allegedly found on new electric cars as they were rolling off the production line.
Further, it found people who raised objections to this, faced retaliation including being fired.
The case was lodged by the EEOC's office in the tech hub of Silicon Valley and is being led by former FBI lawyer James Baker.
Tesla has been contacted for comment.

This suit follows another lawsuit by Californian-based regulators about similiar issues. Earlier this year, Tesla agreed to pay one worker several million dollars after a federal jury found it failed to prevent severe racial harassment at the Californian plant.
Read
more of the suit here
